subject: Add TrustedModuleRequiredToBoot setter function
commitMessage:
Add TrustedModuleRequiredToBoot setter function

TrustedModuleRequiredToBoot is a Redfish ComputerSystem v1_14_0
property, determining if a working TPM is required in order to boot
the host. The TPM Required property is mapped to the "TPMEnable" D-Bus
property. The possible values for the Redfish property are "Required"
and "Disabled".

This commit will add the PATCH operations to the
TrustedModuleRequiredToBoot Redfish property.
(See https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/43930
for the GET operations for this property).

Testing:

1) Curl Testing: I manually tested retrieving the property:
*Default value of TrustedModuleRequiredToBoot is ??Required??

curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" -X PATCH -d \
'{"TrustedModuleRequiredToBoot":false}' \
https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Systems/system

curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" \
https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Systems/system
{
  "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Systems/system",
  "@odata.type": "#ComputerSystem.v1_14_0.ComputerSystem",
...
  "Boot": {
    "AutomaticRetryAttempts": 3,
    ??
    "RemainingAutomaticRetryAttempts": 3,
    "TrustedModuleRequiredToBoot": "Disabled"
  },
...

On HW: D-Bus TPMEnable shows up correctly as 'false'
'# busctl get-property xyz.openbmc_project.Settings \
/xyz/openbmc_project/control/host0/TPMEnable \
xyz.openbmc_project.Control.TPM.Policy TPMEnable'
b false

2) Redfish Validator Testing: Tested on ComputerSystem v1_14_0 schema
    Validator Test everything passed and 0 failures.

Signed-off-by: Ali Ahmed <ama213000@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ie96a6afca179e45bef35813a3fa9c8a10cdf234e

Considering it's still doing an extra GetSubTree call, no, I don't think I'm good.  it should ideally follow the example I posted, which cuts the dbus mapper calls in half for a resource that's already pulling a lot of data, and I suspect will also reduce the size of the patch quite a bit.

I'm of the opinion that all of these inventory interfaces need some standardization;  As every single one does things differently, and a lot of them cause bugs.  This would be similar to the readJson stuff we created years ago for the same reasons.

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 1c05dae3011628e5726eefc3ec4dbe7733fbb4d5 by Gunnar Mills
This is setting the new value
why change this..? This is the GET
This change was supposed to be on line 1409
Done
Done
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/43761 has another check here for             if (service.empty()) but don't think it is needed
Done
Done

Still think you need a 
                messages::internalError(aResp->res); 
here since the user PATCHed it. 

(or messages::resourceNotFound if this is hit when "xyz.openbmc_project.Control.TPM.Policy" is not found but I believe that is the "if (subtree.size() == 0)" so internalError I think makes more sense)
This looks wrong, GetSubTree will return an error code if the object isn't found.  This is an instance of common error #11.

I used to think the same thing, but I think if GetSubTree doesn't find the object it just returns an empty array. I'm going to let Ali test and tell us for sure. ;) 

dbus-send --system --print-reply --dest=xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper /xyz/openbmc_project/object_mapper xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper.GetSubTree string:"/" int32:0 array:string:"garbage.item.inventory"
method return time=1628015868.551455 sender=:1.72 -> destination=:1.147 serial=2180 reply_serial=2
   array [
   ]

In my testing, GetSubTree does return an empty array if there is input interfaces are incorrect. My output is the same as Gunnar's above.

Additionally, I receive a resourceNotFound error from getSubTree if the input root is incorrect.

dbus-send --system --print-reply --dest=xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper /xyz/openbmc_project/object_mapper xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper.GetSubTree string:"/abc/" int32:0 array:string:"xyz.bopenbmc_project.Control.TPM.Policy"

Error xyz.openbmc_project.Common.Error.ResourceNotFound: path or object not found

> In my testing, GetSubTree does return an empty array if there is input interfaces are incorrect. My output is the same as Gunnar's above.


> 
> Additionally, I receive a resourceNotFound error from getSubTree if the input root is incorrect.


You say that your results are the same as gunnars, then you link results below that show that they're different.  FWIW, I would've expected what you saw, but it's odd we're getting different behavior here.

> 
> dbus-send --system --print-reply --dest=xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper /xyz/openbmc_project/object_mapper xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper.GetSubTree string:"/abc/" int32:0 array:string:"xyz.bopenbmc_project.Control.TPM.Policy"
> 
> Error xyz.openbmc_project.Common.Error.ResourceNotFound: path or object not found

This is not an empty array.





Ok, I'm not understanding here.  When I run Gunnars test, I get an empty array, when I run your test, I get the Not Found error.  what I suspect is when the object path exists, but doesn't have matching interfaces (as it does in gunnars test) the mapper returns an empty array.

When the object path doesn't exist, it returns an error.  I think because we can't assume that any give path exists, we have to handle the error here?  It would be really nice if we could just make the mapper consistent again.

I'm sorry I should have made it more clear.

The difference between Gunnar and I tests is that I changed the 'subtree' parameter to 'GetSubTree', i.e the first input parameter. I changed it from "/" to "/abc/", the latter of which is bogus and caused such an error.

In Gunnar's code, he changed only the 3rd input parameter of GetSubTree, interfaces. He changed it away from a valid interface ("xyz.openbmc_project.Control.TPM.Policy") to something bogus (""garbage.item.inventory").

From https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/architecture/object-mapper.md:

GetSubTree

Use this method to find the objects, services, and interfaces in the specified subtree that implement a certain interface. If no interfaces are passed in, then all objects/services/interfaces in the subtree are returned. If interfaces are passed in, then only those interfaces are returned in the output.

Inputs:

param: subtree - the root of the tree. Using "/" will search the whole tree
param: depth - the maximum depth of the tree past the root to search. Use 0 to search all
param: interfaces - an optional list of interfaces to constrain the search to

To summarize:

On input testing for GetSubTree:


1) Param: subtree. Enter invalid value ==> error (as you expected to see)
2) Param: depth. Enter invalid value ==> default to 0 which is used to search unlimited depth
3) Param: interfaces. Enter invalid value ==> empty array (as Gunnar's command shows)

# dbus-send --system --print-reply --dest=xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper /xyz/openbmc_project/object_mapper xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper.GetSubTree string:"/" int32:0 array:string:"garbage.item.inventory"
method return time=1628793723.954168 sender=:1.12 -> destination=:1.150 serial=3575 reply_serial=2
   array [
   ]

# dbus-send --system --print-reply --dest=xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper /xyz/openbmc_project/object_mapper xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper.GetSubTree string:"/garbage" int32:0 array:string:"garbage.item.inventory"
Error xyz.openbmc_project.Common.Error.ResourceNotFound: path or object not found

# dbus-send --system --print-reply --dest=xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper /xyz/openbmc_project/object_mapper xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper.GetSubTree string:"/garbage" int32:0 array:string:"xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Dimm"
Error xyz.openbmc_project.Common.Error.ResourceNotFound: path or object not found

I still think this should be an internal error since the path here is / and hitting that 2nd and 3rd above should not be possible. 
We cover the 1st in that if below.

Not sure this comment makes complete since..
// If interface is not found, set error and return
Just remove the comment, it's clear what's happening from the code.

This check handles Common Error #11 that was alluded at line 1376. If GetSubTree fails to find the anything for the "xyz.openbmc_project.Control.TPM.Policy", it returns an array of size 0 and the resourceNotFound error is caught here.
Done
This should really be "TrustedModuleRequiredToBoot"
This shouldn't even be resource not found.  the resource might be there, but doesn't support this parameter.  This is going to be a fun one to get the error codes right on.

I don't see a better error message. 
Redfish has a "ActionNotSupported": { but no "PropertyNotSupport". 

resourceNotFound is what we do other places, e.g. https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/systems.hpp#L2177 

I can open an issue with Redfish for "PropertyNotSupport" if you agree that makes sense here.

"the resource might be there, but doesn't support this parameter."
Can I ask what does this mean? 

Is maybe the proper place to catch a 'PropertyNotSupported' would be at the inner async_method_call at 1419 that attempts to access the dbus 'xyz.openbmc_project.Control.TPM.Policy' 'TPMEnable' property? 

If it fails to support the parameter, is it possible to just leave TPMEnable in the 'Disabled' state?

(This assumes 'PropertyNotSupported' is added to error_messages and is the correct error for this case.)

I think we should drive PropertyNotSupported with Redfish (if Ed is in agreement, I'll open an issue with them), I don't see a better error message now. 
I think Redfish would call this a Property since I don't see parameter used expert for Action Parameter or Query Parameter in the messages. 
https://redfish.dmtf.org/registries/Base.1.10.0.json

In other places we've used PropertyValueNotInList to defer when a given property was not supported on a given resource.

In this case, it could also be PropertyNotWritable, because we're talking about an optional interface here?
Changed to PropertyValueNotInList
I'm not sure PropertyValueNotInList is better than resourceNotFound but idc. I'll open an issue with Redfish and we can handle later.
This needs combined with the existing GetSubTree method calls instead of duplicating the code here.

This code is based on PowerModes which has a GetSubTree for both GET and PATCH.
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/systems.hpp#L2224
Can you explain more what you are thinking here?

I'm sorry. I thought the proper method to access dbus service and objectPath objects was to use ObjectMapper?

Are we trying to move GetSubTree calls to the BMCWEB_ROUTES and pass variables down to set and get functions? Something like this https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/885bbf1c82ea9f9cbfbe0065ee46adc8e398c868/redfish-core/lib/processor.hpp#L1130?

>This code is based on PowerModes which has a GetSubTree for both GET and PATCH.


That's my point.  You should have a single GetSubtree call with the interfaces you care about in one spot, not two.  As-is this duplicates the call, and has performance impacts (double the dbus calls) for clients that don't implement a TPM at this address.


Here's an example of what I would expect here, for processors:
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/885bbf1c82ea9f9cbfbe0065ee46adc8e398c868/redfish-core/lib/processor.hpp#L765

Notice, it adds all the inventory and accelerator interfaces.  In the future if I ever get time to add the GetSubTreeEx call to the mapper, the code gets further simplified in the future, but for the moment, that pattern is still faster, and minimizes dbus traffic, as well as reduces the amount of code.

This is the PATCH. Now I could agree with you on the GET, we could combine to have 1 mapper call vs 2.

I think a much more common case (90% use case) for PATCH is where the client isn't PATCHing both TPM and PowerModes but instead just PATCHing one.
Yep.... missed that bit.  was going too quickly through.
